Some government researchers have come up with a new idea for improving fuel economy -- the cool seat.

The Department of Energy's National Renewable Energy Laboratory reported on Thursday that if every car and truck on America's roads was equipped with ventilated seats, air-conditioning-related gasoline consumption could be reduced by 7.5 percent, thus saving 522 million gallons of fuel per year.
The seats tested have two built-in fans that suck warm air and moisture through their perforated leather and send it away from the driver or passenger.
Ventilated seats make drivers feel cooler, so they could save fuel by turning their air-conditioners down a notch, in theory.
''But try telling that to some guy driving through Mississippi on a hot day in July,'' said David Caldwell, a spokesman for Cadillac.
The seats, ComfortCools, made by W.E.T. Automotive Systems of Germany, are offered as an option in the Cadillac STS.

Mr. Caldwell says 30 to 40 percent of STS models are ordered with ventilated seats, but only as part of $3,000 to $10,000 luxury packages that also include some features (including a heated steering wheel) that actually make the car less fuel-efficient.

Closely related to the ventilated seat is the heated and air-conditioned ''climatized'' seat with its own refrigeration unit, seen in an increasing number of upscale vehicles. Cooled seats are hot, but they're not exactly fuel savers.
